## Questions

Consider the same data you used for A2 from the spreadsheet "Table_10.1_Renewable_Energy_Production_and_Consumption_by_Source.xlsx". The data comes from the US Energy Information and Administration and corresponds to the December 2025 Monthly Energy Review. This time you will work only with the following columns: 
**Total Renewable Energy Production**; and 
**Hydroelectric Power Consumption**.

Create a data frame structure with these two time series only.

##Trend Component

### Q1

For each series (Total Renewable Production and Hydroelectric Consumption) create three plots arranged in a row (side-by-side): (1) time series plot, (2) ACF, (3) PACF. Use cowplot::plot_grid() to place them in a grid.

```{r}
# function to create all three plots for a given series
create_plots <- function(series, description){
  time_series_plot <- ggplot(energy_data, 
                             aes(x = month, y = series)) + 
    geom_line() + 
    scale_x_date(expand = c(0,0)) +   # compress x axis
    theme_classic() + 
    labs(x = "Month", 
         y = glue("Total {description} (Trillion Btu)"), 
         title = glue("Time Series of\n{description}")) 
  
  acf_plot <- ggAcf(series, lag.max = 40) +
    theme_classic() +
    labs(title = glue("{description} ACF"))
  
  pacf_plot <- ggPacf(series, lag.max = 40) +
    theme_classic() +
    labs(title = glue("{description} PACF"))
  
  cowplot::plot_grid(time_series_plot, acf_plot, pacf_plot, 
                     ncol = 3)
}

# Series 1: Renewable Production
create_plots(energy_data$total_renewable_energy_production, 
             "Renewable\nProduction")

# Series 2: Hydroelectric Consumption
create_plots(energy_data$hydroelectric_power_consumption, 
             "Hydroelectric\nConsumption")
```


### Q2

> Answer: Renewable Energy Production appears to have a strong positive linear trend over time, although this trend seems to stall over the period 1985â€“200. ### Q3

Use the *lm()* function to fit a linear trend to the two time series. Ask R to print the summary of the regression. Interpret the regression output, i.e., slope and intercept. Save the regression coefficients for further analysis.

```{r}
t <- c(1:nrow(energy_data))

# Total Renewable Energy Production
linear_model_renewable <- lm(energy_data$total_renewable_energy_production~t)
summary(linear_model_renewable)

# save coefficients
renewable_b0 <- linear_model_renewable$coefficients[1] %>% as.numeric()
renewable_b1 <- linear_model_renewable$coefficients[2] %>% as.numeric()

# Hydroelectric Power Consumption
linear_model_hydro <- lm(energy_data$hydroelectric_power_consumption~t)
summary(linear_model_hydro)

# save coefficients
hydro_b0 <- linear_model_hydro$coefficients[1] %>% as.numeric()
hydro_b1 <- linear_model_hydro$coefficients[2] %>% as.numeric()

```

> Interpretation: The linear trend fit to the renewable energy production data is positive with an adjusted r-squared value of 0.8201, meaning 82% of variation in this series can be explained by the linear trend over time. These results are significant with a p-value less than 0.05. The linear trend fit to the hydroelectric consumption data is negative with an adjusted r-squared value of 0.02343, meaning only 2.34% of variation in the data can be explained by this trend. This trend is significant with a p-value < 0.05. 

### Q4

Use the regression coefficients to detrend each series (subtract fitted linear trend). Plot detrended series and compare with the original time series from Q1. Describe what changed.

```{r}
# function to detrend series
detrend_series <- function(series, b0, b1, description){
  # subtract linear trend
  series_detrend <- series - (b0 + b1*t)
  
  # x-axis values
  months <- seq(first(energy_data$month), last(energy_data$month),   
                by = "month")  
  
  # combine values into a df to plot
  df_to_plot <- data.frame("month" = months, 
                           "series" = series, 
                           "series_detrend" = series_detrend) %>% 
    pivot_longer(cols = c("series", "series_detrend"), 
                 names_to = "series") %>% 
    mutate(series = factor(series, 
                           levels = c("series", "series_detrend"), 
                           labels = c(glue("Observed {description}"), 
                                      glue("Detrended {description}")))) 
  # plot both time series
  time_series_plot <- ggplot(df_to_plot) + 
    geom_line(aes(x = month, y = value, color = series)) + 
    theme_classic() + 
    theme(legend.position = "bottom") + 
    labs(x = "Month", 
         y = glue("{description} (Trillion Btu)"), 
         title = glue("Detrended {description}"), 
         color = NULL)
    
  return(list(series_detrend, time_series_plot))
}

# detrend renewable energy production
renewable_detrended <- detrend_series(energy_data$total_renewable_energy_production, 
                                      b0 = renewable_b0, b1 = renewable_b1, 
                                      description = "Renewable Energy Production")

renewable_detrend_series <- renewable_detrended[[1]] # save detrended series object
renewable_detrended[[2]]   # show plot

# detrend hydroelectric power consumption
hydro_detrended <- detrend_series(energy_data$hydroelectric_power_consumption, 
                                  b0 = hydro_b0, b1 = hydro_b1, 
                                  description = "Hydroelectric Power Consumption")

hydro_detrend_series <- hydro_detrended[[1]]   # save detrended series object
hydro_detrended[[2]]   # show plot
```

> Answer: Both detrended series no longer have a trend component and their values are centered around 0. For hydroelectric power consumption, the shape of the detrended series appears the same and only the values have been shifted down. The series of renewable energy production appears to have been flattened out. 

### Q5

Plot ACF and PACF for the detrended series and compare with the plots from Q1. You may use plot_grid() again to get them side by side to make it easier to compare. Did the plots change? How?

```{r}
plot_detrend_acf <- function(series, detrend_series, description){
  plot_acf <- ggAcf(series) + 
    theme_classic() + 
    labs(title = glue("ACF of {description}"))
  
  plot_pacf <- ggPacf(series) + 
    theme_classic() + 
    labs(title = glue("PACF of {description}"))
  
  plot_acf_detrend <- ggAcf(detrend_series) + 
    theme_classic() + 
    labs(title = glue("ACF of Detrended {description}"))
  
  plot_pacf_detrend <- ggPacf(detrend_series) + 
    theme_classic() + 
    labs(title = glue("PACF of Detrended {description}"))
  
  cowplot::plot_grid(plot_acf, plot_pacf, plot_acf_detrend, plot_pacf_detrend, 
            ncol = 2, nrow = 2)
}
# Renewable Energy Production
plot_detrend_acf(energy_data$total_renewable_energy_production, 
                 renewable_detrend_series, 
                 "Renewable Energy Production")

# Hydroelectric Power Consumption
plot_detrend_acf(energy_data$hydroelectric_power_consumption, 
                 hydro_detrend_series, 
                 "Hydroelectric Power Consumption")
```

> Answer: There is a slight change in the ACF and PACF for the renewable energy production detrended series. For these data, the seasonal component is a bit more pronounced in the ACF and PACF of the detrended series where there appears to be a slight spike in autocorrelation at around 12 lags. There appears to be no change in the ACF and PACF for the detrended hydroelectric power consumption series.

### Q7

Use function *lm()* to fit a seasonal means model (i.e. using the seasonal dummies) to the two time series. Ask R to print the summary of the regression. Interpret the regression output. From the results, which series have a seasonal trend? Do the results match you answer to Q6?

```{r}
# create time series objects
start <- c(first(year(energy_data$month)), first(month(energy_data$month)))

renewable_ts <- ts(energy_data$total_renewable_energy_production, 
                   start = start, frequency = 12)
hydro_ts <- ts(energy_data$hydroelectric_power_consumption, 
               start = start, frequency = 12)

# create seasonal dummies
dummies <- seasonaldummy(renewable_ts)

# fit seasonal means model to both series
# Renewable Energy Production
renewable_seasonal_model <- lm(renewable_ts ~ dummies)
summary(renewable_seasonal_model)

# Hydro Power Consumptions
hydro_seasonal_model <- lm(hydro_ts ~ dummies)
summary(hydro_seasonal_model)
```
